body:
@marco-c Hey, as there is no PR for this issue I would like to take it.
As this is my very first open source contribution I would be very grateful if you helped me out. I went through the file repository.py but still am not clear where should I close the hg server, 
1. is it in the clear function at line 757? (I don't think the hg server is being closed there too, please have a look)
2. or do we have to close the HG server opened by `_init` function, the initializer of `ProcessPoolExecuter`?

I think it would be the second one, if so, should I use the global variable and append it every time , like in the link you provided and close all the servers before returning the commits?

Thanks

Yes, it's 2.
In 1 we are already closing the hg server, as we are using a context manager https://github.com/mozilla/bugbug/blob/17ff6ed31569fa893e13b8a1140bd1f458765a70/bugbug/repository.py#L758.

@harsh020 note that this is a good-first-issue as it is self-contained, but it is not a good-first-issue if you don't have experience with Python and knowledge of how multiprocessing works. Feel free to propose a PR if you manage to fix it, or to switch to some other good-first-issue if this one is too hard.

> I think it would be the second one, if so, should I use the global variable and append it every time , like in the link you provided and close all the servers before returning the commits?

If you use a global variable, each process will have its own copy, so this won't work.

> In 1 we are already closing the hg server, as we are using a context manager.

@marco-c Sorry, I did not notice that.

> if you don't have experience with Python and knowledge of how multiprocessing works. 

yup, not much experience, but I wanna learn, and I'll read more about multiprocessing, not a problem.

> If you use a global variable, each process will have its own copy, so this won't work.

I'm not thinking to declare a global variable, but the `_init` function itself has a `global HG`, should I simply append them in a list and close all of the servers before returning the commits?

Thanks

> yup, not much experience, but I wanna learn, and I'll read more about multiprocessing, not a problem.

OK! Note: for `multiprocessing` I'm not just talking about the `multiprocessing` module, but concepts about working with multiple processes in general, if you don't know them you'll need to read about them too.

> I'm not thinking to declare a global variable, but the _init function itself has a global HG, should I simply append them in a list and close all of the servers before returning the commits?

Sure, you can do that, but you need to share the list between all processes.

> for multiprocessing I'm not just talking about the multiprocessing module, but concepts about working with multiple processes in general

Yes, I'm on it. Threading (drawbacks bcs of GIL) and multiprocessing.

> Sure, you can do that, but you need to share the list between all processes.

I was thinking of creating a global list to make it accessible to all process like in the link you provided.

Thanks.

> I was thinking of creating a global list to make it accessible to all process like in the link you provided.

As I said earlier, a global list won't work because global variables are not shared between processes. Each process will have its own copy.

@marco-c Won't just declaring the list outside the function do the job? Thats interesting.
So, should I use multiprocessing manager instead?
This might take a while.

Thanks.
@harsh020 I told you this requires a bit of experience with multiprocessing concepts :)
@harsh020 Multiprocessing has `Value` and `Array` that gets shared between processes. Global variables aren't shared since each process has it's own copy/address space.

@marco-c Sorry for the delayed reply, I'm still studying the concepts and if I am able to solve this issue i'll first let you know the approach.

> I told you this requires a bit of experience with multiprocessing concepts :)

Yup, very true.

Thanks.
